# Sean Hayes (actor)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

(disambiguation)](/wiki/Sean_Hayes_\(disambiguation\) "Sean Hayes
\(disambiguation\)").

Sean Hayes  
---  
[![Sean Hayes
\(portrait\).jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Sean_Hayes_%28portrait%29.jpg/220px-
Sean_Hayes_%28portrait%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sean_Hayes_\(portrait\).jpg) Hayes
in 2010  
Born | Sean Patrick Hayes  
(1970-06-26) June 26, 1970 (age 47)  
[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"),
U.S.[1]  
Occupation | Actor, comedian, producer  
Years active | 1996–present  
Spouse(s) | Scott Icenogle (m. 2014)  
  
**Sean Patrick Hayes**[2] (born June 26, 1970)[1] is an American actor,
comedian, and producer. He is best known for his role as [Jack
McFarland](/wiki/Jack_McFarland "Jack McFarland") on the [NBC](/wiki/NBC
"NBC") sitcom _[Will& Grace](/wiki/Will_%26_Grace "Will & Grace")_, for which
he won an [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award"), four [SAG
Awards](/wiki/SAG_Award "SAG Award"), and one American Comedy Award, and
earned six [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe "Golden Globe")
nominations.[3][_[verification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] He also runs a television production company
called Hazy Mills Productions, which produces shows such as
_[Grimm](/wiki/Grimm_\(TV_series\) "Grimm \(TV series\)")_ , _[Hot in
Cleveland](/wiki/Hot_in_Cleveland "Hot in Cleveland")_ , _[The Soul
Man](/wiki/The_Soul_Man "The Soul Man")_ , and _[Hollywood Game
Night](/wiki/Hollywood_Game_Night "Hollywood Game Night")_.

He is known for his film work in movies such as _[Cats&
Dogs](/wiki/Cats_%26_Dogs "Cats & Dogs")_, _[Pieces of
April](/wiki/Pieces_of_April "Pieces of April")_ , _[The Cat in the
Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\) "The Cat in the Hat \(film\)")_ , _[Win
a Date with Tad Hamilton!](/wiki/Win_a_Date_with_Tad_Hamilton! "Win a Date
with Tad Hamilton!")_ , _[The Bucket List](/wiki/The_Bucket_List "The Bucket
List")_ , and _[The Three Stooges](/wiki/The_Three_Stooges_\(2012_film\) "The
Three Stooges \(2012 film\)")_.

He is also known for his work on Broadway such as _[An Act of
God](/wiki/An_Act_of_God "An Act of God")_ and _[Promises,
Promises](/wiki/Promises,_Promises_\(musical\) "Promises, Promises
\(musical\)")_ , where he played Chuck Baxter and received a nomination for
[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Performance_by_a_Leading_Actor_in_a_Musical
"Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical").

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sean_Hayes_\(actor\)&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Hayes was born in Chicago, the youngest child of Mary Hayes,[4] the director
of a non-profit [food bank](/wiki/Food_bank "Food bank"),[1] and Ronald Hayes,
a [lithographer](/wiki/Lithographer "Lithographer").[1] He is of
[Irish](/wiki/Irish_people "Irish people") descent and was raised as a [Roman
Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") in the [Chicago
suburb](/wiki/Chicago_suburbs "Chicago suburbs") of [Glen Ellyn,
Illinois](/wiki/Glen_Ellyn,_Illinois "Glen Ellyn, Illinois"). His father left
when Hayes was five years old, and he and his siblings were raised by their
mother. He has not spoken to his father in many years.[2][4]

After graduating from [Glenbard West High
School](/wiki/Glenbard_West_High_School "Glenbard West High School"),[5] Hayes
attended [Illinois State University](/wiki/Illinois_State_University "Illinois
State University"),[4] where he studied [piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano")
performance.[6] He left "two or three classes short" of graduation when he
became [music director](/wiki/Music_director "Music director") at the Pheasant
Run Theater in [St. Charles, Illinois](/wiki/St._Charles,_Illinois "St.
Charles, Illinois").[6]

Hayes worked as a [classical](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music")
[pianist](/wiki/Pianist "Pianist").[7] He practiced improv at [The Second
City](/wiki/The_Second_City "The Second City") in Chicago.[8] He also composed
original music for a production of _[Antigone](/wiki/Antigone_\(Sophocles\)
"Antigone \(Sophocles\)")_ at the [Steppenwolf Theatre
Company](/wiki/Steppenwolf_Theatre_Company "Steppenwolf Theatre Company") in
Chicago.[9] He moved to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") in
1995,[8] where he found work as a [stand-up comedian](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy
"Stand-up comedy") and an actor on stage and[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] on
television, including a [commercial](/wiki/Television_commercial "Television
commercial") for [Doritos](/wiki/Doritos "Doritos")[8] which aired during
[Super Bowl XXXII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXII "Super Bowl XXXII") in 1998.

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sean_Hayes_\(actor\)&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

As a teenager, Hayes was an extra in the film _[Lucas](/wiki/Lucas_\(film\)
"Lucas \(film\)")_ (1986), which was filmed at [his high
school](/wiki/Glenbard_West_High_School "Glenbard West High School"). He made
his professional debut in the [independent film](/wiki/Independent_film
"Independent film") _[Billy's Hollywood Screen
Kiss](/wiki/Billy%27s_Hollywood_Screen_Kiss "Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss")_
(1998), which brought him wide attention. The same year, he was cast as [Jack
McFarland](/wiki/Jack_McFarland "Jack McFarland"), a flamboyantly
[gay](/wiki/Gay "Gay") and frequently unemployed actor, in the [NBC](/wiki/NBC
"NBC") comedy series _[Will& Grace](/wiki/Will_%26_Grace "Will & Grace")_. The
show became a long-running hit and Hayes' performance earned him seven
consecutive [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") nominations as
[Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actor_in_a_Comedy_Series
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series").
He won the award for his first nomination.[3][_[verification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] He was also
nominated for six [Golden Globe Awards](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe
Award") for his performance.

Hayes also made film appearances in _[Cats& Dogs](/wiki/Cats_%26_Dogs "Cats &
Dogs")_ (2001), as [Jerry Lewis](/wiki/Jerry_Lewis "Jerry Lewis") in _[Martin
and Lewis](/wiki/Martin_and_Lewis_\(film\) "Martin and Lewis \(film\)")_
(2002), Wayne in _[Pieces of April](/wiki/Pieces_of_April "Pieces of April")_
(2003), _[The Cat in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\) "The Cat in
the Hat \(film\)")_ (2003), and _[Win a Date With Tad
Hamilton!](/wiki/Win_a_Date_With_Tad_Hamilton! "Win a Date With Tad
Hamilton!")_ (2004). He was also the voice of Brain in the 2008 film
_[Igor](/wiki/Igor_\(film\) "Igor \(film\)")_ , and has guest starred in
television shows such as _[Scrubs](/wiki/Scrubs_\(TV_series\) "Scrubs \(TV
series\)")_ and _[30 Rock](/wiki/30_Rock "30 Rock")_. In 2005, he was
[executive producer](/wiki/Executive_producer "Executive producer") for
[Bravo](/wiki/Bravo_\(U.S._TV_channel\) "Bravo \(U.S. TV channel\)")'s
_[Situation: Comedy](/wiki/Situation:_Comedy "Situation: Comedy")_ , a
[reality television](/wiki/Reality_television "Reality television") series
about sitcoms. He also executive produced _[The Sperm
Donor](/wiki/The_Sperm_Donor "The Sperm Donor")_ and _Stephen 's Life_, the
two winning scripts that were chosen by NBC. He guest-starred in 2006 in the
[Adult Swim](/wiki/Adult_Swim "Adult Swim") [cameo](/wiki/Cameo_appearance
"Cameo appearance")-filled show _[Tom Goes to the
Mayor](/wiki/Tom_Goes_to_the_Mayor "Tom Goes to the Mayor")_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Hayes appeared as Thomas in the film _[The Bucket List](/wiki/The_Bucket_List
"The Bucket List")_ (2007). On July 5, 2008, he made his New York stage debut
as Mr. Applegate / Devil in [New York City Center](/wiki/New_York_City_Center
"New York City Center")'s _[Encores!](/wiki/Encores! "Encores!")_ production
of _[Damn Yankees](/wiki/Damn_Yankees "Damn Yankees")_.[2]

He also appeared as Mr. Hank Hummerfloob and the voice of "The Fish" in _[The
Cat in the Hat](/wiki/The_Cat_in_the_Hat_\(film\) "The Cat in the Hat
\(film\)")_. In a 2008 _[New York Times](/wiki/New_York_Times "New York
Times")_ interview, Hayes talked about a television project, _BiCoastal_ ,
about "a guy with a wife and kids in California and a boyfriend in New
York"[2] for [Showtime](/wiki/Showtime_\(TV_network\) "Showtime \(TV
network\)").[10] He made his Broadway debut in the April 2010 Broadway revival
of the musical _[Promises, Promises](/wiki/Promises,_Promises_\(musical\)
"Promises, Promises \(musical\)")_. He received a nomination for the [Drama
League Award](/wiki/Drama_League_Award "Drama League Award") for Distinguished
Performance, and was nominated for a [Tony Award for Best Actor in a
Musical](/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Musical "Tony Award for Best
Actor in a Musical").

Hayes was host of the [64th Annual Tony Awards](/wiki/64th_Tony_Awards "64th
Tony Awards") on June 13, 2010 on CBS.[11] In 2010, he reprised the role of
Mr. Tinkles, the evil white Persian cat, in _[Cats& Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty
Galore](/wiki/Cats_%26_Dogs:_The_Revenge_of_Kitty_Galore "Cats & Dogs: The
Revenge of Kitty Galore")_. On November 15, 2010, he appeared in a satirical
PSA for the repeal of [Don't Ask, Don't Tell](/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell
"Don't Ask, Don't Tell") on _[The Daily Show with Jon
Stewart](/wiki/The_Daily_Show_with_Jon_Stewart "The Daily Show with Jon
Stewart")_. He played [Larry Fine](/wiki/Larry_Fine "Larry Fine") in the film
_[The Three Stooges](/wiki/The_Three_Stooges_\(2012_film\) "The Three Stooges
\(2012 film\)")_ (2012).[12]

Aware that his role in _Will & Grace_ "wouldn't go on forever",[13] Hayes
teamed up with his friend Todd Milliner, whom he met at Illinois State
University,[5] to create the television production company Hazy Mills
Productions in 2004.[13][14][15][16] The company has produced multiple
American television series, including _[Hot in
Cleveland](/wiki/Hot_in_Cleveland "Hot in Cleveland")_ ,
_[Grimm](/wiki/Grimm_\(TV_series\) "Grimm \(TV series\)")_ , _[The Soul
Man](/wiki/The_Soul_Man "The Soul Man")_ , _[Hollywood Game
Night](/wiki/Hollywood_Game_Night "Hollywood Game Night")_ and _[Sean Saves
the World](/wiki/Sean_Saves_the_World "Sean Saves the World")_.[16] Hayes is
co-executive producer of the [TV Land](/wiki/TV_Land "TV Land") original
comedy series _[Hot in Cleveland](/wiki/Hot_in_Cleveland "Hot in Cleveland")_
, which premiered in June 2010.[17] He is also a co-executive producer of the
[NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") series _[Grimm](/wiki/Grimm_\(TV_series\) "Grimm \(TV
series\)")_ ,[18] as well as creator and executive producer on another NBC
series, _[Hollywood Game Night](/wiki/Hollywood_Game_Night "Hollywood Game
Night")_.[19]

Hayes and his husband, Scott Icenogle, produce lip-sync videos under their
YouTube channel, The Kitchen Sync.[20] They lip-synced to songs such as
_[Trouble](/wiki/Trouble_\(Iggy_Azalea_song\) "Trouble \(Iggy Azalea song\)")_
& _[Burnitup!](/wiki/Burnitup! "Burnitup!")_ He was the host of _An All Star
Tribute to James Burrows_.

Hayes starred in the Broadway play _[An Act of God](/wiki/An_Act_of_God "An
Act of God")_ , which ran from June 6, 2016 to September 4, 2016.

In 2017, Hayes played the role of Steven, the [devil](/wiki/Devil "Devil")
emoji in _[The Emoji Movie](/wiki/The_Emoji_Movie "The Emoji Movie")_.

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sean_Hayes_\(actor\)&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Hayes refused to discuss his [sexual orientation](/wiki/Sexual_orientation
"Sexual orientation") for many years, saying he believed that audiences would
therefore be more open-minded about his characters.[21] In a 2010 interview
with _[The Advocate](/wiki/The_Advocate "The Advocate")_ , he appeared to
imply that he is [gay](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality"), stating: "Really?
You're gonna shoot the gay guy down? I never have had a problem saying who I
am. I am who I am." He also indicated that he was in a relationship. He states
that he feels like he has "contributed monumentally to the success of the gay
movement in America, and if anyone wants to argue that, I'm open to it".[8]

He received an [honorary](/wiki/Honorary_degree "Honorary degree")
[PhD](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy "Doctor of Philosophy") from [Illinois State
University](/wiki/Illinois_State_University "Illinois State University") in
February 2013.[6]

In November 2014 Hayes announced that he had married his partner of eight
years, Scott Icenogle.[22]

In October 2017, while appearing on an episode of
[Ellen](/wiki/The_Ellen_DeGeneres_Show "The Ellen DeGeneres Show"), Hayes
revealed that he had a rare condition that made his small intestine burst
open. After spending time in the hospital, Hayes got his intestine fixed.[23]
